case_name: Rajendra Ram Doss Jee Varu v. Devendra Doss Jee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 407 N of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 407  N  of 1971. Appeal by certificate from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from judgment and decree dated September 21, 1970 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. No. 476 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and decree dated September 21, 1970 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. No. 476 of 1966. C. Chagla, M. X. Cardoze, E. C. Agarwala and A.T.M. Sampath, for the

facts.text: Dispute regarding succession to office of Mohunt of Sri Swami Hathiramjee Mutt, Tirumalai Tirupati.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate from a judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh arises out of a dispute re- garding the succession to the office of the spiritual head  Mohunt  of Sri Swami Hathiramjee Mutt, Tirumalai Tirupati.

facts.text: Succession to Mohunt regulated by custom: senior disciple becomes next mohunt, subject to being North-Indian Brahmin.

anchor.surface_text: Succession to the office of the Mohunt of the Mutt is admittedly regulated by custom which provides that upon the death of a mohunt his senior disciple becomes the next mohunt. This is, however, subject to the companydition that the senior disciple must be a North-Indian Brahmin.

facts.text: Sri Prayagadasjee Varu was Mohunt in 1947 and died in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In 1947 Sri Prayagadasjee Varu was the Mohunt of the Mutt. Upon his death in 1947 there was a dispute about the succession to the office of Mohuat between two companytestants viz. Sri Narayanadasjee Varu and Sri Chetandossjee Varu.

facts.text: 1947 dispute between Sri Narayanadasjee Varu and Sri Chetandossjee Varu resolved by Akada Panchayat via compromise Ex. B-8: Narayanadasjee Mohunt, then Chetandoss, then senior disciple of Narayanadasjee.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute appears to have been resolved by the intervention of what is described as the Supreme Council of Mohunts viz the Akada Panchayat. Under the terms of companypromise which are to be found in Ex. B-8, Sri Narayanadasjee Varu became the Mohunt and after him, the office was to devolve on Chetandoss and after Chetandoss on a senior disciple of Narayandasjee Varu.

facts.text: Narayandasjee Varu died in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Narayandasjee Varu died in 1958 and there was again a dispute as to who would become the next mohunt.

facts.text: 1958 dispute: Chetandoss vs Rajendra Ram Doss Jee Varu (appellant), settled by Ex. B-1: Chetandoss succeeds Narayanadasjee, then Rajendra Ram Doss.

anchor.surface_text: Chetandos claimed to be the mohunt under the terms of Ex. B-8 while Sri Rajendra Ram Doss Jee Varu the present appellant before us claimed the office by virtue of his status as a senior disciple of Narayanadasjee Varu. ... Under this agreement Chetandoss was to succeed Narayanadasjee Varu and, after Chetandoss, the office was to go to Rajendra Ram Doss.

facts.text: Chetandoss died on 18 March 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Very soon after this, however, on 18 March 1962 Chetandoss died.

facts.text: Post 1962 death, Rajendra Ram Doss claimed Mohunt per agreements and as surviving disciple of Narayanadasjee; Devendra Doss Jee (respondent) claimed as senior disciple of Chetandoss.

anchor.surface_text: Rajendra Ram Doss claimed to be the mohunt in terms of the two agreements we have referred to just number and also by virtue of his being the only surviving disciple of Narayanadasjee Varu. Devendra Doss Jee, the respondent in this appeal, however, put up a claim to the office of mohunt by virtue of his position as a senior disciple of the last reigning mohunt Chetanctoss.

facts.text: Suit filed on behalf of minor Devendra Doss by next friend Sri Mukundadas jee Varu for declaration of title to Mohunt office and properties, and injunction against Rajendra Ram Doss.

anchor.surface_text: He was, however, a minor at that time and a suit was filed on his behalf by his next friend Sri Mukundadas jee Varu, Mohunt of Bugga Mutt, Tirupati. In that suit he claimed for declaration of his title to the office of the mohunt with all the properties that are attached to that office as well as an injunction against Rajendra Ram Doss Jee Varu restraining him from interfering with the affairs of the Mutt.

facts.text: At trial, both parties agreed: by immemorial custom, senior most disciple succeeds; only North-Indian Brahmin entitled.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the trial of the suit it both parties agreed about two propositions By immemorial custom and practice, upon the death of a mohunt his eldest or senior most disciple succeeds to the Gaddi and Only a North- Indian Brahmin is entitled to be a mohunt.

facts.text: Each party contended other not North-Indian Brahmin.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended by each party before the learned subordinate Judge that the other party was number a North- Indian Brahmin.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held Rajendra Ram Doss was North-Indian Brahmin and entitled as senior disciple of Narayanadossjee; Chetandoss period a break in custom.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge held that the defendant Rajendra Ram Doss was a North-Indian Brahmin and was also entitled to succeed as the senior disciple of Narayanadossjee Varu. According, to the learned Subordinate Judge the period of mohuntship of Chetandoss was to be treated as a break in the practice of the customary rule

facts.text: High Court found Rajendra Ram Doss not North-Indian Brahmin, Devendra Doss senior disciple of Chetandoss, entitled; upheld plaintiff's appeal, granted declaration and injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found on facts that Narayan Doss was number a North-Indian Brahmin and was, therefore, number entitled to being companysidered as a possible successor to the office of the mohunt. The High Court further held that since Devendra Doss was the senior disciple of Chetandoss he should by the rule of custom succeed to the office of the mohunt upon the death of Chetandoss.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted High Court finding that Rajendra Ram Doss not North-Indian Brahmin, Devendra Doss is.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after carefully examining the evidence on record has companye to a clear finding on facts that Rajendra Ram Doss was number a North-Indian Brahmin. The High Court has also found that the respondent Devendra Doss was a North-Indian Brahmin.

facts.text: Ex. B-1 dated 15 July 1961 recites Rajendra Ram Doss as North-Indian Brahmin.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there is a recital in Ex. B-1 which is the agreement executed by and between Chetandoss and Rajendra Ram Doss on 15 July 1961, that Rajendra Ram Doss was a North-Indian Brahmin.

facts.text: High Court found Ex. B-1 recital suspicious; overall evidence shows Rajendra not North-Indian Brahmin.

anchor.surface_text: Far from treating this as an evidence in support of Raendra Ram Dosss companytention that he was a North-Indan Brahmin the High Court companysiders this to be a very suspicious recital. ... Apart from this solitary evidence of Ex. B-1 the entire evidence on record goes to show that Rajendra Ram Doss was number a NorthIndian Brahmin.

facts.text: Estoppel from Ex. B-1 not applicable as defendant joined issue on Brahmin status at trial.

anchor.surface_text: Even though a clear plea of estoppel arises from the recital in Ex. B-1 the defendant did number rely on this plea and entered into an issue on the facts so that the whole matter became open for the decision of the learned Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, held Devendra Doss entitled as senior disciple of Chetandoss per custom.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we hold that Devendra Doss is entitled to succeed Chetan Doss as his senior-most disciple on the strength of the immemorial custom of this Mutt. In the view that we take of this matter the appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Ex. B-8 dated 29 October 1947.

Whether Devendra Doss, as senior-most North-Indian Brahmin disciple of Chetandoss, is entitled to succeed to the office of Mohunt under the immemorial custom?

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the trial of the suit it both parties agreed about two propositions By immemorial custom and practice, upon the death of a mohunt his eldest or senior most disciple succeeds to the Gaddi and Only a North- Indian Brahmin is entitled to be a mohunt.

arguments.claim: Customary rule prevails except for interregnum of Chetandoss; ignore his period entirely so succession reverts to senior disciple of Narayanadasjee Varu (Rajendra Ram Doss).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chagla appearing for the appellant raised two contentions in support of the appellants claim. First, he contended that the customary rule by which a senior disciple succeeds to the Gaddi of a mohunt upon the death of a reigning mohunt has always prevailed in this Mutt except for what may be described as an interregnum when Chetandoss was installed as the Mohunt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot ignore Chetandoss's period entirely; reversion to custom must start from his death, not Narayanadasjee's, to reestablish custom; Rajendra ineligible anyway.

arguments.claim: Devendra Doss estopped from denying Rajendra Ram Doss is North-Indian Brahmin due to recitals in Ex. B-1 (15 July 1961) and Ex. B-8 (29 Oct 1947), as claiming through Chetandoss who was party to agreements.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, Mr. Chagla argued that Devendra Doss, the respondent, is bound by the agreement of 15 July 1961 which not only recognised that Rajendra Ram Doss was a North-Indian Brahmin but also Stipulated that Rajendra Ram Doss as the only surviving disciple of Narayanadass should become the Mohunt of the Mutt.

holdings.text: High Court findings that Rajendra Ram Doss was not a North-Indian Brahmin and Devendra Doss was a North-Indian Brahmin are correct and not manifestly wrong.

anchor.surface_text: This Court is not generally inclined to set aside or ignore the findings on fact of the High Courts unless they appear to have been manifestly wrong. In this case, however, after going through the evidence ourselves we are clearly of the opinion that the High Court was right in its findings that the plaintiff was a North-Indian Brahmin while the defendant was a South-Indian lyengar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent review of evidence confirms High Court findings; not inclined to disturb unless manifestly wrong.

holdings.text: No estoppel applies from recital in Ex. B-1 as defendant did not plead it and instead joined issue on the fact of North-Indian Brahmin status.

anchor.surface_text: Even though a clear plea of estoppel arises from the recital in Ex. B-1 the defendant did not rely on this plea and entered into an issue on the facts so that the whole matter became open for the decision of the learned Subordinate Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant waived estoppel by litigating the factual issue; precedents like Young v. Raincock and Greer v. Kettle confirm.

holdings.text: Chetandoss's period of mohuntship cannot be ignored as non-existent; reversion to custom operates from the point of his death, not Narayanadasjee's.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ignoring period breaks succession irreparably; Annasami principle correct but requires reestablishment from last holder's death to preserve custom.

holdings.text: Devendra Doss is entitled to succeed Chetandoss as senior-most disciple under immemorial custom requiring North-Indian Brahmin.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we hold that Devendra Doss is entitled to succeed Chetan Doss as his senior-most disciple on the strength of the immemorial custom of this Mutt. In the view that we take of this matter the appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies admitted custom to facts: Devendra qualifies as senior disciple of last mohunt and North-Indian Brahmin.

precedents.cited_proposition: If the estoppel appears on the record but the party entitled to it goes to issue on the fact instead of relying on it, the matter is put at large and the estoppel may be disregarded.
precedents.cited_holding: where it can be collected from the deed that the parties to it have agreed upon a certain admitted state of facts as the basis on which they contract, the statement of those facts, though put in the way of recital, shall estop the parties to aver the contrary, yet refused to treat the recital as conclusive because party went to issue on the fact.

precedents.cited_proposition: Confirmation of the principle that estoppel from recitals in agreements does not preclude proving the true facts if the parties have litigated the issue.
precedents.cited_holding: Doubting Lainson v. Tremere as authoritative, approving the view in Young v. Raincock that going to issue on the fact puts the matter at large.

anchor.surface_text: 1834 1 AD EL. 792. Then, his Lordship quotes with approval the observation of Coltman J. in Young and Anr. v. Raincock 1  which we have already cited above. In the light of the foregoing companysiderations we see numberreason to discard the finding of fact recorded by the High Court to the effect that Devendra Doss was a North-Indian Brahmin and Rajendra Ram Doss was number. We number companye to the first companytention of Mr. Chagla. Starting from the proposition which is admitted by both parties to the suit ,and which states that by immemorial custom the office of Mohunt upon the death of a reigning mohunt goes to the latters senior most disciple, Mr. Chagla companytends that by this test Chetan Doss companyld number have become the Mohunt when he assumed that office ,as a result of the two agreements embodied in Ex. B-8 and Ex. B-1.

precedents.cited_proposition: Statements in deeds estop all parties from ever alleging and proving the true facts.

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 28 Mad. 219. As we have already seen, it is number possible to make Rajendra Ram Doss the Mohunt for the simple reason that he has been found number to be a North-Indian Brahmin. Even on the assump- tion that Rajendra Ram Doss was the senior-most disciple of Narayan Doss at the time of the latters death and, therefore, satisfies the requirement of one customary rule, Rajendra Ram Doss cannot become the Mohunt according to the other equally customary rule that only a North-India Brahmin can be the Mohunt of this mutt. In our opinion the rule of custom should prevail in all cases and if any aberrations have to be companyrected such companyrection must take us in the direction of reestablishing the rule of custom. To that extent the principle laid down in the case of Annasami Pillai and Ors. v. Ramakrishna Mudaliar and Anr.  supra  is a companyrect principle and has to be followed.

precedents.case_name: Annasami Pillai and Ors. v. Ramakrishna Mudaliar and Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: A trustee who acquires title by prescription but restores the office to the person who would have succeeded according to the founder's rule should not be treated as an exception to the non-assignability of trusteeship; it restores the customary management.
precedents.cited_holding: it would seem number unreasonable to hold that where a person, who had number right to the office of a trustee according to the rule of devolution established by the founder, acquires a title to the office by prescription, but restores it to one, who, except for the transferors prescriptive title, companyld have taken the office according to the rules laid down by the founder, such transfer should be treated as an exception to the general doctrine that a trusteeship is number assignable.

anchor.surface_text: This Court is not generally inclined to set aside or ignore the findings on fact of the High Courts unless they appear to have been manifestly wrong. In this case, however, after going through the evidence ourselves we are clearly of the opinion that the High Court was right in its findings that the plaintiff was a North-Indian Brahmin while the defendant was a South-Indian lyengar.
In the view that we take of this matter the appeal fails and is dismissed. In the peculiar circumstances of this case we make numberorders to companyts.
